title: Mazda recalls 35,000 cars sold between 2012 and 2018 including Mazda3, CX-5 and Mazda6
text:
Mazda is recalling more than 35,000 popular cars that were sold brand new in Australia during the past seven years.

The Japanese car maker has announced there are faults with the shutter intake valve that could pose a serious safety risk to drivers - the latest and most serious in a string of recalls this year.

It affects Mazda3s sold new between 2014 and 2016, diesel CX-5 SUVs sold from 2012 until last year and Mazda6 models made between 2012 and 2018.

Mazda is recalling more than 35,000 popular cars that were sold brand new in Australia during the past seven years. It affects Mazda3s (pictured) sold new between 2014 and 2016, diesel CX-5 SUVs sold from 2012 until last year and Mazda6 models made between 2012 and 2018

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has announced the fault could cause the cars to emit smoke from the engine compartment, gradually drop engine power and stall without being able to restart.

'If any of the above symptoms occur, there is an increased risk of an accident or injury to vehicle occupants and other road users,' it said.

The affected vehicles may accumulate carbon deposits in the intake shutter valve, on top of extra premature wear to certain engine components, the ACCC said.

The fault could activate multiple warning lights on the dashboard.

The intake valve is designed to stop the car vibrating after the engine has been turned off.

The Mazdas being recalled also have a stop-start feature, known as iStop, that automatically prevents the engine from idling when a driver stops at the traffic lights.

Mazda Australia is contacting 35,476 affected owners to arrange a time for repairs at no cost to them, once parts become available.

The potentially faulty cars were sold between January 2012 and August last year.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has announced the fault could cause the cars to emit smoke from the engine compartment, gradually drop engine power and stall without being able to restart (pictured is a 2015 Mazda3 which is affected by the recall)

Is your Mazda affected? Mazda4 (BM series): model years 2014 to 2016 Mazda6 (GJ, GL series): 2012 to 2018 Mazda CX-5 (KE, KF series): 2012 to 2018 Diesel vehicles only The recall affects 35,476 vehicles Source: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission Product Safety Australia recall issued on October 10, 2019

In July, Mazda recalled 18,700 cars amid fears a faulty software program designed to save fuel could in fact cause the car to lose power and stall without the ability to restart.

It affected the Mazda3, CX-5 and Mazda6 like this latest recall.

During that same month, the latest model Mazda3 was also recalled over concerns the wheels could fall off.

In May, previous-shape Mazda3s built between 2015 and 2017 were recalled over fears the front windscreen wipers could be defective in heavy rain, causing an accident.

The Mazda CX-5 was Australia's sixth most popular car last month, Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries sales data showed.

The Mazda3, however, slipped off the top 10 list for the first time since the replacement for the long-running 323 model debuted in 2004.

It had been Australia's bestselling car in 2011 and 2012.

Motorists who require more information are advised to call Mazda's customer support on 1800 034 411
description: Mazda is recalling more than 35,000 cars sold brand new in Australia since 2012. A fault with the intake valve poses a threat to drivers of the Mazda3, CX-5 and Mazda6.
authors: Stephen Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
